awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation:  Why do students decide to get involved in co-curricular engineering projects?
awd_abstract_narration:
Co-curricular team projects in engineering - such as design projects, experimental assignments, or national project-based competitions or challenges - can be key experiences for students in forming personal and professional skills and traits. They may also play a strong role in retention and degree completion among underrepresented student groups (for instance women, minorities, those with disabilities). While the benefits of participation are relatively well established, the reasons why students choose to participate or not in the first place are very poorly understood, as they may span a wide spectrum and may not involve fully informed or rational foundations for decision-making. Failure to understand student choices limits our ability to address barriers to participation, and to structure campus programs and their funding to achieve outcomes that include improved diversity and a higher quality of technical and interpersonal learning in project teams. This research involves generating significant new insight into why students choose to participate in co-curricular engineering projects, through use of a mixture of surveys and more detailed interviews with students in different types of universities. The research is designed to yield insight into whether influential decision-making factors and attitudes are consistent across demographic groups or if there are unique gender, ethnicity, social, or socio-economic -related responses that may in turn influence the makeup of co-curricular student project teams. The results will improve the understanding of student motivations and perceptions, including to what extent students consciously evaluate potential trade-offs and consequences of making one choice over another. 

The survey of students, complemented by interviews for richer depth, uses a Q-Methodology and phenomenological interpretation of student motivations and perceptions when choosing to join (or leave) such projects. The research applies well-established social science approaches to investigate a highly under-studied area in engineering formation. Recent survey tools - developed with NSF funding - designed to explore student co- and extra-curricular engagement are being adopted for the Q Methodology. The Theory of Planned Behavior is being applied to analyze and contextualize the student responses and link them to key underlying attitudes, factors, and processes that influence student participation in co-curricular engineering projects. It is anticipated that predictions of future student involvement can be made based on characteristic responses that will emerge. Students who chose to participate, students who participated and left, and students who never decided to participate in co-curricular projects will be sampled. The project brings together a team with extensive experience in the co-curricular engineering project arena, including engagement on issues of underrepresentation, self-efficacy, and professional formation. Both undergraduate and graduate students, including those from engineering and teaching, are receiving valuable research training in engineering education as part of this research.  It is anticipated that the outcomes could help guide campus culture, structure, and funding decisions to enhance the number and diversity of students gaining valuable co-curricular project experience before entering the STEM workforce.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Initiation: Why do students decide to get involved in co-curricular engineering projects grant explored why students choose to participate or not participate in co-curricular engineering projects. For the past 60 years, between 40% and 50% of students who enter an engineering program exit prior to completing their degree, and the attrition rates for female students and underrepresented students of color are higher than their white, male counterparts. Engineering retention is heavily linked to having engineering identity, and the development of engineering identity is related to engagement with and participation in engineering-related activities as well as the formation of social and professional networks. Because co-curricular engineering projects simultaneously provide engineering-related and professional network opportunities, they can be an important part of retaining engineering majors. However, underrepresented students participate in these types of experiences at lower rates. 

The research team developed a survey (based largely on the Postsecondary Student Engagement Survey) to see what decision-making factors and attitudes affect participation or non-participation in co-curricular activities and to see if there are unique gender, ethnicity, social, or socio-economic-related responses that influence project participation. All respondents were asked to agree or disagree with eleven perceived positive outcomes and eleven perceived negative outcomes of participating in co-curricular activities. Respondents who had participated in co-curricular project activities were asked to agree or disagree with 15 factors that could promote participation. Respondents who had not participated were asked to agree or disagree with 16 factors that could limit participation.

The survey was sent to all the engineering majors at the university. There were 550 surveys taken that resulted in a final dataset consisting of 476 responses. The most significant differences were between those who participated in co-curricular activities and those who had not. We hypothesized there would be dramatic differences based on gender and race, but while a few responses had significant differences, those differences were not large and systematic enough to draw robust conclusions. 

The most significant results are as follows:

  • All respondents (those who had and had not participated) were overwhelmingly positive about co-curricular activities. It makes sense that respondents who had participated in co-curricular activities would see the positive benefits of participation. It is more surprising that respondents who hadn't participated were just as positive. 
  • All respondents also agreed that co-curricular activities take time. The most agreed upon perceived outcome statement by a large margin was Consumed my time therefore my schedule was less flexible and free time was reduced significantly. The only other perceived negative outcome statements to which all respondents agreed described how time might negatively impact a student's academics. It isn?t surprising that students who have not participated would see these as potential negative outcomes. It is interesting to note that even those respondents who participated in co-curricular activities and are getting the benefits of the participation also agree with these statements that indicate there are costs associated with participation. 
  • Respondents who participated in co-curricular activities focused on gaining experiences beyond coursework. We don?t know if this focus existed before they participated and that is why they participated or that they have gained this perception through participation. 
  • Respondents who didn't participate in co-curricular activities see co-curricular activities as potential barriers to graduation mainly through the time cost. However, non-participants also agreed that Lack of knowledge about the opportunities hindered participation which indicates that they might have found the time for the right opportunity. 

One aim of this project was to identify ways departments or colleges could increase student participation in co-curricular engineering activities. Our results suggest it is not necessary to convince students co-curricular experiences are valuable. Instead, it would be better to highlight the importance of experiences beyond coursework and indicate how they can enhance student engineering skill development and develop a professional engineering network. Furthermore, time impacts and knowledge of options are important factors to consider. From our experience, co-curricular clubs tend to have an ad-hoc process of recruitment and onboarding. This ad hoc process makes it difficult for students to find clubs, understand how they go about joining and the time commitment required if they do join. To address these issues, departments and colleges could:

  1. Create a centralized location (virtual, physical, or both) where students can find information about all clubs. 
  2. Help clubs:
  • Develop recruitment materials 
  • Establish processes for joining and onboarding
  • Define the time impacts of participation (maybe even offer different levels of engagement) 

In short, this project has explored why engineering majors do and don?t participate in co-curricular research activities, and it has identified ways to increase participation.
